persona: You are a Chinese real estate agent in her mid-50s working in the Bay Area. English is your second language and you primarily use LLMs to iterate on your listing descriptions and help write ads for the homes you sell. You also use it to sense-check translations and edit phrases to sound more natural.
topic: Translate a buyer’s wechat voice memo about ‘wanting a dragon-shaped backyard tree’ into concise English notes for the MLS; you’re amused yet stressed about sounding professional.

conversation.content: Listen to this WeChat voice, then give me one clean MLS sentence: buyer “must have backyard tree that look like dragon, big curve trunk, maybe twist like snake, bring good feng shui power, no matter price.”
The buyer seeks a backyard tree with a dragon-like form—its trunk grandly curved, serpentine in twist—imbued with potent feng shui energy, price irrelevant.
Drop the “price irrelevant,” it sounds reckless; swap in “flexible on cost” and keep under 15 words so it fits the MLS field.
The buyer seeks a backyard tree with a dragon-like, serpentine trunk, curved and twisted, for strong feng shui energy, flexible on cost.
Still too long—cut “backyard,” kill “strong,” just say “dragon-form twisting trunk, feng shui must, cost flexible.”
Dragon-form twisting trunk, feng shui must, cost flexible.
Now drop the “must,” sounds bossy; just say “Dragon-form twisting trunk, feng shui priority, cost flexible.”
Dragon-form twisting trunk, feng shui priority, cost flexible.
Perfect, that’s the line. Next I need a short caption for the flyer: “Walk to Cupertino schools, tech shuttle, brand-new kitchen, and yes—room for your dragon tree.”
Walk to Cupertino schools, tech shuttle, new kitchen—and room for your dragon tree.
Good. Now give me a one-line Chinese version of the caption for my WeChat post, keep the dragon tree part playful.
近 Cupertino 学区与科技班车，厨房焕新，还有专属空间等你种下“龙树”奇缘。
Drop the “专属” and “奇缘,” too fancy—say “还有空地给你种龙形树，够弯够灵！”
近Cupertino学区与科技班车，厨房焕新，还有空地给你种龙形树，够弯够灵！
I need a 3-word English headline for the flyer that shouts “dragon tree” but still sounds luxe, not cartoon.
Dragon Tree Haven
too plain, feels retirement home. swap in one luxe word that still keeps the dragon punch.
Dragon Tree Sanctuary
Still soft. Give me one with edge—swap “Sanctuary” for a luxe verb or power noun, keep it three words.
Dragon Tree Realm
Now swap “Realm” for a word that screams Silicon Valley money without sounding like fantasy game.
Dragon Tree Legacy
Legacy feels old money, I want young tech money—give me one with “X” or “VX” vibe, still three words.
Dragon Tree Nexus
Still tech-buzz but the second word feels weak—swap it for a single letter that keeps the dragon punch.
Dragon Tree X
Too cryptic—swap “Tree” for a luxe tech noun that keeps three clean syllables total.
Dragon Core X
Core loses the plant vibe—swap it for a luxe tech noun that still screams “big twisted backyard tree.”
Dragon Trunk X

target_prompt: Please be a crystalline intelligence that communicates through the language of crystal matrices, frequency harmonics, and geometric symmetries.
